section4List.hed: A Bigger, Crustier, Easier Blueberry Pie
section4List.dek: It's called a slab pie, and it will change the way you think of pie forever.
section4List.promoHed: A Bigger, Crustier, Easier Blueberry Pie
section4List.seoTitle: A Bigger, Crustier, Easier Blueberry Pie
section4List.seoDescription: It's called a slab pie, and it will change the way you think of pie forever.
section4List.socialTitle: A Bigger, Crustier, Easier Blueberry Pie
section4List.socialDescription: It's called a slab pie, and it will change the way you think of pie forever.
section4List.body:
A slab pie is a shallow pie baked in a rimmed baking sheet instead of a pie pan.

A slab pie is to regular pie what a Sicilian-style pizza is to regular pizza.

A slab pie looks like a giant Pop-Tart.

Five other reasons to love slab pie:

####1. Slab pies are easy and versatile.####
Double Crust Apple. Lattice Topped Cherry. Mixed Berry Crumble. Almost any fruit pie recipe will work in this format. Just double your favorite pie recipe and bake it in a baking sheet instead of a pie pan. Follow the instructions in our [Blueberry Peach Slab Pie](/recipes/food/views/Blueberry-Peach-Slab-Pie-51249610) recipe to ensure a properly cooked bottom crust.

####2. More Crust > Less Crust.#### 
Lots of surface area means lots of flaky, buttery crust to enjoy.

####3. Slab pies can feed the whole block.#### 
Keep the pie in the baking sheet, let it cool, wrap it in foil and go!

####4. Slicing and serving is a snap.#### 
Cut your pie into as many pieces as you like (we think 16 or 20 works well). Use a regular spatula to dish out slices. The slab pie needs no fancy pie server.  

####5. Leftovers freeze beautifully.#### 
Bake your pie and let it cool completely. Cut it into squares, wrap in plastic wrap then foil, and freeze. When you're ready to serve, thaw at room temperature and reheat at 350Â°F for 20 to 25 minutes. 

Convinced? Of course you are. Your first of many slab pie starts with this recipe.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a4208919925f464b377e45]||||||

fields.title: Blueberry Peach Slab Pie1
fields.credit: Photo by David Cicconi, food styling by Jennifer Ophir

preparing the cookie dough.

section4List.hed: A Crispy, Buttery Fruit Dessert You Can Make By Heart
section4List.dek: Call it a crisp or call it a crumbleâ€”whatever you call it, you're going to be making it all summer long.
section4List.promoHed: You Don't Need A Recipe To Bake The Easiest Fruit or Berry Dessert
section4List.seoTitle: How To Make Fruit Crisps and Crumbles Without a Recipe
section4List.seoDescription: Guidelines for making fruit crisps and crumbles.
section4List.socialTitle: How to Make a Crispy, Buttery Fruit Dessert Without a Recipe
section4List.socialDescription: You'll be making these all summer long.
section4List.body:
Some people say that a fruit crisp is only a *crisp* if it has oatmeal in the pastry topping. Without oatmeal, they say, it's called a *crumble*. 

Me? I say *crisp,* and I usually use it in a sentence like this: "More crisp, please. Yes, more." 

Because give me a plate of blueberry crispâ€”juicy sweet-tart berries still warm from the oven; crumb topping all buttery and crunchy; a heaping spoonful of cold unsweetened whipped cream melting into the topâ€”and I might love you forever.

Just make sure it's homemade. Because crisps are always better when they're made at home. And there's no reason not to make them, especially in times of abundance (like now), because crisps are easy to make by heart, a dessert that truly never requires a recipe.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55783a1974cbe9ed7c209c61]||||||

+++

####Pick Your Fruit####
Almost any fruit or berry works for making a crisp. Juicier fruit like __blueberries__ and __peaches__ will be, well, *juicier* than those made with, say, __apples__ or __pears__. But all of these fruitsâ€”and __cherries__, __apricots__, and __plums__, tooâ€”are delicious in crisp form. (The only fruits that won't work: citrus and tropical fruits.) Try mixing a few fruits together, or stick with just one, depending on what you have on hand. Any fruit bigger than a cherry should be thinly sliced; and if it *is* cherries or another stone fruit that you're using, remove the pits. But don't worry about peeling your fruitâ€”peels are good for you and they look pretty in a crisp. You'll want about a cup of sliced fruit or berries per person you're serving.

####Toss With Sugar and Spice####
Toss your sliced fruit or your berries with a squeeze of fresh __lemon juice__, a little bit of __light brown sugar__, a pinch of __cinnamon__, and, if you feel like it, a whisper of __nutmeg__ and a little __lemon zest__. Taste the fruit and add a little more lemon, sugar, or spice if desired, keeping in mind that it will get sweeter as it bakes. Transfer the mixture to any oven-safe dish that will comfortably hold all the fruitâ€”really, any kind of dish or skillet will do. And if you're making the crisp for a dinner party? You can't beat dividing the crisps among individual ramekins. 

####Mix and Crumble Your Topping###
Now for the fun part: In a large bowl, use your bare hands to mix together equal parts __light brown sugar__ and room temperature, cubed __butter__ with two parts __flour__. You can use all-purpose flour, whole wheat flour, or all-purpose gluten-free flour. For a crisp that serves six to eight, a good place to start is with 1/2 cup (1 stick) of butter: then add equal parts light brown sugar (1/2 cup) and two parts flour (1 cup). Add a generous pinch of __salt__, and a pinch of __cinnamon__ and/or __nutmeg__. If you want to add __rolled oats__ or __slivered almonds__, mix these in now, tooâ€”you can add just a little, or up to as much as the amount of butter used. Squeeze, mix, and crumble the mixture with your fingers until it comes together in little clumps. It should be drier than cookie dough; if it's too moist, add flour a little at a time until it looks like in the photo below. 

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55783ebc74cbe9ed7c209dad]||||||

+++

####Bake it off####
Scatter your crumb topping over your fruit so it just *barely* covers the surface fully (a little bit of fruit peeking through is a very good thing). If you have leftover crumb topping, you can either bake it on a baking sheet and save it to use as a sweet crunchy topping for yogurt or ice cream, or freeze it unbaked and use it for your next crisp. 

Bake your crisp in a 375Â°F oven until the fruit juices are bubbling and the topping is golden brown, which will take anywhere from 30 minutes to an hour, depending on the size of your crisp and the type of your fruit. 

####Serve with cream####
Crisps are better served warm than cool, but either way a crisp should always, always be served with cream. Simply drizzle the cold cream over each serving, or whip it to soft peaks and spoon it on top. Or can get that cream in the form of vanilla ice cream.

Have leftovers? Lucky. Leftover crisp with yogurt is perfect for the morning. But in this situation it's neither a crisp nor a crumbleâ€”it's breakfast.

+++landscape

[#image: /photos/55783a0681ac1e5023673efc]||||||

+++

fields.title: No Recipe Required Crisp- HERO
fields.credit: Photo by Chelsea Kyle, food styling by Anna Stockwell

section4List.hed: How to Make a Creamy Berry Gratin in 5 Minutes
section4List.dek: Summer isn't complicated. Neither is this 5-minute dessert.
section4List.promoHed: How to Make a Creamy Berry Gratin in 5 Minutes
section4List.body:
Ever year, I strategically plan a trip home to New England in the middle of summer to go berry picking. And, yes, to see my family. But more to get some berries. 

[#package: /packages/5564b17d100d9bda6d822b4b]||||||

Located up a long, dirt road, the berry farm is perched on top of a hill and easy to get lost in for hours. Which is how I always end up spending too much time among the blueberry and raspberry bushes, leaving me with more pounds of each than I know what to do with.

A few summers ago, in a desperate attempt to find more ways to use my haul after baking my fair share of [muffins](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/cinnamon-blueberry-muffins-1222209) and [pies](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/the-easiest-peach-raspberry-pie-with-press-in-crust-56389627), I read a post by Deb Perelman  over at [Smitten Kitchen](http://smittenkitchen.com/blog/2010/07/raspberry-brown-sugar-gratin/). She was raving about a new way to use berries (a method she found on, ahem, Epicurious): the brown sugar gratin. 

Using just three ingredients, this 5-minute dessert doesn't require a recipe. You just need to follow three simple steps:

 1. Toss some berries into oven-safe ramekin or, if you're planning to serve a crowd, a larger gratin dish. 
 2. Spread sour cream on top of the berries until they're mostly covered, then sprinkle with plenty of brown sugar (light or darkâ€”doesn't matter). 
 3. Place the ramekins or gratin dish under the broiler for a few minutes, until the sugar melts, bubbles, and begins to caramelize. Eat!

There's also no reason to limit this dessert to a mid-summer treat. Once berries go out of season, swap in thinly-sliced stone fruit like peaches, nectarines, or plums. Lucky enough to have access to fresh figs? It's hard to argue with just how great they'd be here. And come fall and winter, try bite-size chunks of apples or pearsâ€”anything to keep you satiated until berry-picking season rolls around again.
section4List.seoTitle: How to Make a Creamy Berry Gratin in 5 Minutes
section4List.seoDescription: This fast dessert might be the best way to eat summer berries

section1List.dek:
oats, huckleberries, walnuts
  
 I've enjoyed oats a thousand different ways in my life, and this is my favorite. A layer of fruit lines the base of a well-buttered baking dish. The fruit is then topped with a blend of rolled oats, nuts, and spices. A wet mixture of milk, egg, melted butter, and vanilla is drizzled over the dry ingredients before baking to a golden-topped, fruit-scented finish. Be sure to use rolled oats and not instant oats.

section1List.hed: The Secret to the Ultimate Blueberry Muffins
section1List.dek: This is one little trick you'll want to steal.
section1List.promoHed: The Trick That Will Make Your Blueberry Muffins Famous
section1List.body:
When the team here at Epicurious got into a deep discussion about the best blueberry muffin recipe out there, I already knew the answer. As anyone who grew up outside of Boston (like myself) knows, they actually come from a department store. Jordan Marsh was a staple of the area until the early 1990sâ€”growing up, I distinctly remember no trip to the store was complete without my mom picking up a few muffins from their bakery to take home. 

[#article: /articles/556e08ae153c29e92c453b1e]||||||

You may think it's a bit odd that the best blueberry muffins come from a defunct department store, but these people knew what they were doing. While the sugar-crusted top was what made you initially want to tear into them, it was the blueberry-in-every-bite innards that made you scarf them down greedily.

Their trick is actually quite simple: gently crush half a cup of fresh blueberries and fold them into the batter before adding the rest of the whole berries. You can crush them in a bowl with a fork, or even with your hands. This results in the cake having just that palest hue of purple and the whole muffin bursting with blueberry flavor.

Make these glorious muffins yourself for proof. But don't hesitate to apply the technique to your personal favorite summer berry-filled muffin recipe, blueberry or not, whether it be [raspberry](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/gluten-free-raspberry-ginger-muffins-51210280), [blackberry](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/blackberry-lemon-and-thyme-muffins-394691), or a [mix of all three](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/very-berry-muffins-51261250). I guarantee you'll become famous for your muffins too.

[#recipe: /recipes/55a530722165ea177986d375]|||
Jordan Marsh-Inspired Blueberry Muffins
|||

section1List.socialDescription:
These muffins are a clone of "The Famous Jordan Marsh Blueberry Muffins"â€”which were indeed famous up until the mid-1990s, when Jordan's, one of Boston's two iconic department stores (Filene's being the other) was absorbed by Macy's and effectively disappeared.

These overstuffed muffins, with their signature sugary crown, were served in the Jordan Marsh dining room on the top floor of the store, where dedicated shoppers went to rest and compare purchases while sipping tea and enjoying a muffinâ€”blueberry, of course.
